name: n-heptyl hydroperoxide
Reason: The target compound n-heptyl hydroperoxide (C7H15OOH) has functional groups that affect its melting point. First, we consider n-heptane, as it is the hydrocarbon backbone of our molecule. The melting point of n-heptane is -90.6°C. Each additional -CH2- group in a straight-chain alkane generally increases the melting point by about 20 to 30°C, but as we already account for heptane, we do not need to add further increase for each methylene group. Hydroperoxides, with their -OOH group, have the ability for hydrogen bonding, which increases the melting point; however, this effect is generally less pronounced than what is observed with alcohols or carboxylic acids due to the less favorable hydrogen bond donor ability of the -OOH group. Comparing to alcohols, which can increase the melting point around 50 to 100°C because of hydrogen bonding, it's reasonable to estimate the increase for a hydroperoxide group would be roughly half of that, so an increase of approximately 25 to 50°C. Thus, combining the base value of n-heptane with the influence of the hydroperoxide, we arrive at an estimated increase in melting point.
